body:
Can confirm on python 3.8.12, current main, windows.

@chillerobscuro said on 0.13.1 this code above ran without error.
FYI @bethrice44 - between 0.13.1 and now, you made some changes, could this be related to those?
@fkiraly It _might_ be related to the way we default `initial_window`. What is the length of `y` here?

The error comes from the reduction wrapper.

I think I understand what is happening - the reducer requires at least max fh plus `initial_window` data, so the conformal forecaster should also have that minimum.

This works:

```python
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor

from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.naive import NaiveForecaster

y = load_airline()

f = make_reduction(
    RandomForestRegressor(),
    scitype="tabular-regressor",
    window_length=16,
    strategy="recursive",
)

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(f, 'conformal', initial_window=20)
conformal_forecaster.fit(y, fh=[1,2,3])
pred_int = conformal_forecaster.predict_interval()
```
where `20 > max(fh) + initial_window = 19`
Ah but the default `initial_window` is `int(0.1*len(y)) = 14`, which is less than the `window_length` for the reduced regressor which it has to fit on so it might be that

So, the one thing that is not explained here why this ran on 0.13.1 without errors but does not run on main.

* @chillerobscuro, can you confirm python and sktime version you tested this on and it ran?
* perhaps it is related to changes in the reduction wrapper then - could that be the case, @danbartl?
Pressed send same time as you! How will the conformal forecaster know its wrapping a reducer?

So I think this was introduced with setting a different default `initial_window` (post 0.13.1) as `0.1*len(y)` which was arbitrary as we discussed to cover _most_ use cases. I wonder if there is a more principled way to set it? Or if we should make it a required arg?

> How will the conformal forecaster know its wrapping a reducer?

from a principled perspective, it shouldn't. Compositors should be non-contextual, and only assume the general `sktime` interface contracts.

As such, minimum requirements on data length may be problematic if the user doesn't put the additional requirements together carefully.

My preference would be no additional requirements above the standard contracts - if they are not satisfied, we can default to a dummy forecast plus warning, instead of raising an exception?

Ok, do we have a standard dummy forecast that is used (`NaiveForecaster` with window of 1 say?) I think we should say in the warning to please set `initial_window` to something that satisfies min data requirements for the chosen forecaster.

> * @chillerobscuro, can you confirm python and sktime version you tested this on and it ran?

Looks like we've already narrowed it down somewhat, but for what it's worth I can confirm it worked on `sktime` version 0.13.1 running python 2.7.18 and 3.9.4

issue.title: [BUG] Error when fitting `ConformalIntervals` with `AutoEnsembleForecaster`

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Combining forecasters in an `AutoEnsembleForecaster` which makes good predictions. I'd like to get conformal predictions for the same ensembled model. It's returning an error related to `_split()`, and I'm treating the Ensemble as a regular forecaster and following the example in the [CI Docs](https://www.sktime.org/en/stable/api_reference/auto_generated/sktime.forecasting.conformal.ConformalIntervals.html).

Looks like there is some parallelism when trying to `_compute_sliding_residuals`, which overly divides the training series. I wonder if there's a straightforward way to avoid this in Ensemble models which may have an arbitrary number of child models, but I haven't dove into the deep logic. I could imagine there are issues with aggregating in sample forecasts for ensemble models but this would be a great feature to have if possible.

On further digging, it seems to work if `len(ytrain)` > `10*len(fh)`. I suppose there might be 10x parallelism. Perhaps we could check the `len`s and reduce `n_jobs` or similar, or provide an explicit warning if there are unavoidable length requirements.

**To Reproduce**

```python
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.compose import AutoEnsembleForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.exp_smoothing import ExponentialSmoothing
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon

y = load_airline()
ytrain, ytest = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=24)
print(len(ytrain), len(ytest))

fh = ForecastingHorizon(ytest.index, is_relative=False)

es = ExponentialSmoothing(sp=12)
ar = ARIMA()

forecasters = [
    ("AR", ar),
    ("ES", es)
]

ae = AutoEnsembleForecaster(forecasters=forecasters, test_size=24, method='inverse-variance')

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(ae)
conformal_forecaster.fit(ytrain, fh=fh)
```
Output:
```
120 24
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
Input In [1], in <cell line: 26>()
     23 ae = AutoEnsembleForecaster(forecasters=forecasters, test_size=24, method='inverse-variance')
     25 conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(ae)
---> 26 conformal_forecaster.fit(ytrain, fh=fh)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py:303, in BaseForecaster.fit(self, y, X, fh)
    301 # we call the ordinary _fit if no looping/vectorization needed
    302 if not vectorization_needed:
--> 303     self._fit(y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh)
    304 else:
    305     # otherwise we call the vectorized version of fit
    306     self._vectorize("fit", y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/conformal.py:150, in ConformalIntervals._fit(self, y, X, fh)
    147 self.forecaster_.fit(y=y, X=X, fh=fh)
    149 if self.fh_early_:
--> 150     self.residuals_matrix_ = self._compute_sliding_residuals(
    151         y=y,
    152         X=X,
    153         forecaster=self.forecaster,
    154         initial_window=self.initial_window,
    155         sample_frac=self.sample_frac,
    156     )
    158 return self

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/conformal.py:411, in ConformalIntervals._compute_sliding_residuals(self, y, X, forecaster, initial_window, sample_frac, update)
    405         warn(
    406             f"Couldn't predict after fitting on time series of length \
    407                          {len(y_train)}.\n"
    408         )
    409     return residuals
--> 411 all_residuals = Parallel(n_jobs=self.n_jobs)(
    412     delayed(_get_residuals_matrix_row)(forecaster.clone(), y, X, id)
    413     for id in y_index
    414 )
    415 for idx, id in enumerate(y_index):
    416     residuals_matrix.loc[id] = all_residuals[idx]

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/parallel.py:1043, in Parallel.__call__(self, iterable)
   1034 try:
   1035     # Only set self._iterating to True if at least a batch
   1036     # was dispatched. In particular this covers the edge
   (...)
   1040     # was very quick and its callback already dispatched all the
   1041     # remaining jobs.
   1042     self._iterating = False
-> 1043     if self.dispatch_one_batch(iterator):
   1044         self._iterating = self._original_iterator is not None
   1046     while self.dispatch_one_batch(iterator):

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/parallel.py:861, in Parallel.dispatch_one_batch(self, iterator)
    859     return False
    860 else:
--> 861     self._dispatch(tasks)
    862     return True

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/parallel.py:779, in Parallel._dispatch(self, batch)
    777 with self._lock:
    778     job_idx = len(self._jobs)
--> 779     job = self._backend.apply_async(batch, callback=cb)
    780     # A job can complete so quickly than its callback is
    781     # called before we get here, causing self._jobs to
    782     # grow. To ensure correct results ordering, .insert is
    783     # used (rather than .append) in the following line
    784     self._jobs.insert(job_idx, job)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/_parallel_backends.py:208, in SequentialBackend.apply_async(self, func, callback)
    206 def apply_async(self, func, callback=None):
    207     """Schedule a func to be run"""
--> 208     result = ImmediateResult(func)
    209     if callback:
    210         callback(result)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/_parallel_backends.py:572, in ImmediateResult.__init__(self, batch)
    569 def __init__(self, batch):
    570     # Don't delay the application, to avoid keeping the input
    571     # arguments in memory
--> 572     self.results = batch()

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/parallel.py:262, in BatchedCalls.__call__(self)
    258 def __call__(self):
    259     # Set the default nested backend to self._backend but do not set the
    260     # change the default number of processes to -1
    261     with parallel_backend(self._backend, n_jobs=self._n_jobs):
--> 262         return [func(*args, **kwargs)
    263                 for func, args, kwargs in self.items]

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/joblib/parallel.py:262, in <listcomp>(.0)
    258 def __call__(self):
    259     # Set the default nested backend to self._backend but do not set the
    260     # change the default number of processes to -1
    261     with parallel_backend(self._backend, n_jobs=self._n_jobs):
--> 262         return [func(*args, **kwargs)
    263                 for func, args, kwargs in self.items]

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/conformal.py:400, in ConformalIntervals._compute_sliding_residuals.<locals>._get_residuals_matrix_row(forecaster, y, X, id)
    398 X_train = get_slice(X, start=None, end=id)
    399 X_test = get_slice(X, start=id, end=None)
--> 400 forecaster.fit(y_train, X=X_train, fh=y_test.index)
    402 try:
    403     residuals = forecaster.predict_residuals(y_test, X_test)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py:303, in BaseForecaster.fit(self, y, X, fh)
    301 # we call the ordinary _fit if no looping/vectorization needed
    302 if not vectorization_needed:
--> 303     self._fit(y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh)
    304 else:
    305     # otherwise we call the vectorized version of fit
    306     self._vectorize("fit", y=y_inner, X=X_inner, fh=fh)

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/compose/_ensemble.py:157, in AutoEnsembleForecaster._fit(self, y, X, fh)
    153     y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(
    154         y, X, test_size=self.test_size
    155     )
    156 else:
--> 157     y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=self.test_size)
    158     X_train, X_test = None, None
    160 # fit ensemble models

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/model_selection/_split.py:1445, in temporal_train_test_split(y, X, test_size, train_size, fh)
   1443 else:
   1444     series = (y,) if X is None else (y, X)
-> 1445     return _train_test_split(
   1446         *series,
   1447         shuffle=False,
   1448         stratify=None,
   1449         test_size=test_size,
   1450         train_size=train_size,
   1451     )

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sklearn/model_selection/_split.py:2448, in train_test_split(test_size, train_size, random_state, shuffle, stratify, *arrays)
   2445 arrays = indexable(*arrays)
   2447 n_samples = _num_samples(arrays[0])
-> 2448 n_train, n_test = _validate_shuffle_split(
   2449     n_samples, test_size, train_size, default_test_size=0.25
   2450 )
   2452 if shuffle is False:
   2453     if stratify is not None:

File ~/Code/ts/notebooks/tsdl/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sklearn/model_selection/_split.py:2071, in _validate_shuffle_split(n_samples, test_size, train_size, default_test_size)
   2063 train_size_type = np.asarray(train_size).dtype.kind
   2065 if (
   2066     test_size_type == "i"
   2067     and (test_size >= n_samples or test_size <= 0)
   2068     or test_size_type == "f"

-> 2071     raise ValueError(

ValueError: test_size=24 should be either positive and smaller than the number of samples 12 or a float in the (0, 1) range
```
